reviewText: I thought that the concert was reasonable though some of the selections such as the Rachmaninov seemed out of place for a New Year's Concert.  Anne Sophie von Otter and Roberto Alagna were excellent as was the violinist Gil Shaham.  The images were clear.  The color good with excellent flesh tones.  The Dolbey Stereo sound was fine, I did not listen to the PCM choice.  I do object to the extreme close-ups of the singers.  I am not convinced that we need to see dental work, tongues and other oral body parts.  I little further away from the singers would still allow one to see facial emotion without the anatomy lessons.  The Berlin Philharmonic was excellent as usual.  There are many other New Year's concert programs that I prefer though the Carmen tribute was worth the material that I didn't care for as much.
summary: the program seemed a bit heavy for a New Year's Gala
Title: N/A

reviewText: This New Year's Eve concert by the Berlin Philharmonic under Abbado from the end of 1997 must surely rank as one of the most consistently exciting and musically rewarding.It starts with a concert selection from Carmen featuring a fine trio of soloists in Anne Sophie van Otter, Bryn Terfel and Roberto Alagna. Of these three Anne Sophie van Otter dominates as Carmen giving a performance of amazing seduction that precedes her fine Glyndebourne operatic performance in the role of some 10 years later. One wonders if this Berlin performance may have had anything to do with her later casting.The Rachmaninov Paganini variations follow with Mikhail Pletnev in scintillating form and adding a much increased level of concert frission to his much admired studio recording with Pesek from the same period. This is one of the best performances I have ever heard and I have many to compare with in my CD collection collected over some 50 years or so.The Sarasate Carmen Fantasy follows in a performance by Gil Shaham that manages to outgun Perlmann's brilliance on CD and matches Sarah Chang's pleasure in performance years later at the Waldebuhne. A truly memorable experience in what is building to be an outstanding concert.This standard continues with a finely perceptive and brilliant performance of Ravel's Rhapsody Espagnole and finishes with de Falla's Firedance and Brahms' 5th Hungarian Dance.So are there any snags? Well yes. The recording is excellent but is in stereo which may bother some purchasers. The screen format is 16:9 and not the 4:3 as rather strangely listed on the disc box. The problem is the actual imaging that is far from sharp on mid to long shots and, as such, falls well below current HD standards. The close-up shots are fine though. For music making of this level however I am definitely prepared to make sufficient allowances for these deficiencies.A grading would therefore be 5 stars for the performances but reduced to 4 because of the technical shortcomings as regards image quality. I would suggest though, that such is the quality and unique nature of this collection of outstanding performances that the gains far outweigh the losses. In this respect I feel I am making a special exception for a special release although there may be others who would disagree and be more put off by the technical deficiencies than myself.
summary: Terrific concert , good stereo but soft imaging on longer shots
Title: N/A

reviewText: Let me start by saying that Amazon's reviewer has made some terrible mistakes in describing the picture.  It IS NOT 16:9.  It is 4:3 as clearly stated on the dvd's back cover.  So, there is no problem with the image being distorted.  Also, even though I played this dvd on a cheap player without progressive scan, there was absolutely no graininess, no out of focus pictures.  In fact the picture was extremely sharp and clear.Performance - Claudio Abbado & Berlin Philharmonic - top of the line.Two soloists really stood out.  Anne Sophie Von Otter's voice was warm and rich, and Gil Shaham's virtuosity on violin was breathtaking.Other reviewers have remarked that this is as good any performance dvd of classical music they've ever seen and I eagerly agree.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this New Year's Gala DVD because I liked the themes associated with Bizet's Carmen, which were prominently featured in the program. Also, well known names like Bryn Terfel, Claudio Abbado, Anne Sophie von Otter and Robert Alagna added to the luster of the evening's performance. The concert was very nice: great orchestra with a world renowned conductor, wonderful singers and then.....there was Gil ShahamI remember as a teen buying an album for a particular song and every so often (rarely) you would find a hidden gem that was unexpected and quite often better than the piece you had originally purchased the album for. Such is the case here: Gil Shaham is a violin virtuoso extraordinaire! His performance of Pablo de Sarasate's Carmen Fantasy op 25 it simply breath taking. The piece is full of joyous energy, technical skill and shows a man that is one with his instrument. An unbelievable performance of a beautiful piece of music that must have been thrilling to have witnessed live.The rest to the disk is very good but this one piece is worth the price of the entire DVD.
summary: This Gala has a hidden gem
Title: N/A

reviewText: The concert in the DVD is full of variety and features world's famous musicians. Otter is really amazing with Carmen. So is Bryn Terfel. Carmen fantasy by Gil Shaham is also my favotite part of the concert. He did wonderful performance with it. Of course, Pletnev's Rachmaninoff is fabulous too. The technical quality of both sound and vision is superb.All in all, this is the best classical music concert DVD I have ever seen and you must own.
Title: N/A
